content:
I’m Tyler Spears, and I’m 20 years old. I go to Georgetown College in Scott County, where I’m majoring in Art and minoring in Computer Science. I’m really like graphic design and want to work in the design field or open my own print shop after college. I like to be creative and bring ideas to life.
I’m also Adobe Illustrator certified, which has helped me in my design work. I enjoy learning new design techniques and exploring different creative styles.
Outside of school, I stay pretty active and social. I have played pickleball over the past few years and i have even won two tournaments. When I’m not playing pickleball i’m ussally playing viedo games or hanging out with my friends or my girlfriend if i’m not doing that then i’m most likly at work or school. I have three dogs named Sheba, Buddy and Cooper and a bird named kiwi.
I have also done quite a bit of traveling across the U.S.. I’ve been to places like Yellowstone, Niagara Falls, and Florida, but my favorite trip so far was definitely Discovery Cove in Florida, where I got to swim with dolphins which has been an unforgettable experience.
I have also worked at Penn Station for about three years, and I’m currently a manager there. I handle most of the everyday operations, solve problems on the fly, and help train new team members. It’s taught me a lot about leadership, teamwork, and communication.
I’m proud to be an Eagle Scout and also completed NYLT (National Youth Leadership Training) through Boy Scouts, which helped me develop strong leadership and problem-solving skills that I carry into school, work, and everyday life.
Thank you for reading my get to know me if you care to learn more about other stuff i have done i have articles and links to the things i like.
Addtional InformationWant to know more about pickleball rules Click Here.Interseted in becoming a boy scout or knowing about ranks Click Here.Want to know more about where I work or hungry for a meal Click Here.
summary: I’m Tyler Spears, and I’m 20 years old. I go to Georgetown College in Scott County, where I’m majoring in Art and minoring in Computer Science. I’m really like graphic design and want to work in the design field or open my own print shop after college. I like to be creative and bring ideas to life.
title: About Me

content:
The first problem we are going to look at is one from the chaper two homework.
ChessBoardWrite a program that creates a string that represents an 8×8 grid, using newline characters to separate lines. At each position of the grid there is either a space or a "#" character. The characters should form a chessboard. Passing this string to console.log should show something like this:# # # # # # # # # # # ## # # # # # # ## # # # # # # ## # # #When you have a program that generates this pattern, define a binding size = 8 and change the program so that it works for any size, outputting a grid of the given width and height.My AnswerExplanation of how the code works below
Here’s some interactive code you can try to test it out:
let size = 8;let board = "";for (let y = 0; y < size; y++) {for (let x = 0; x < size; x++) {if ((x + y) % 2 == 0) {board += " ";} else {board += "#";}}if (y Run Codelet size = 8; let board = “”; for (let y = 0; y < size; y++) { for (let x = 0; x < size; x++) { if ((x + y) % 2 == 0) { board += " “; } else { board += “#”;} } if (y < size - 1) board += “\n”; } console.log(board) ExplanationIn order to explain the code we will take it line by line:let size = 8; this determines the size of the board so in this case it would be an 8x8 board if we changed the number to 9 it would become a 9x9 board and so on as that number changes.let board = "";This makes the board as a string that can be printed out. This allows the board start with empty characters.for (let y = 0; y < size; y++) {this for loop then makes y equal 0 which is like a y-axis on a graph so row 1 gets created then it checks to make sure that y is less than the size that we made the board so in this case y has to be less than 8. Then at the end of this for loop it adds 1 to the y to tell it to go down a row.for (let x = 0; x < size; x++) {this for loop that is in the previous for loop make x equal 0 similar to the other loop with y this does the columns instead of the rows and in order to keep it a square it also has to check to make sure that x is less than the size. after that it adds one to the x and goes until it hits 8 at that point it returns to the previous for loop and does it all again.if ((x + y) % 2 == 0) {this if statement says that if x and y added together are divisible by 2 meaning that if x is 5 and y is 7 then that would be 12 then it would divide until the remainder is either 1 or 0 in this case if the value is 0 then it would do the statement below otherwise it will go to the else.board += " ";this is the statement that if x and y added are divisible by 2 then it will make that spot on the board a blank meaning a space or no character.} else {board += "#";}this else statement says is if the previous statement is not true and x plus y can not be divided by 2 then it is going to make a # on the board.}if (y < size - 1) board += "\n";}this if statement is outside of the second loop but in the first one and this makes the new lines for the board so when the y and x are done with the row they are on this will make a new line this stops before the end as you do not need a new line after the final row.console.log(board)this just produces the code somewhere the viewer can see it so you know it actually works.SourcesClick Here for the link to the textbook for this problem.Click Here for the link to the theme for blowfish on github.
summary:
The first problem we are going to look at is one from the chaper two homework.

ChessBoard

Write a program that creates a string that represents an 8×8 grid, using newline characters to separate lines. At each position of the grid there is either a space or a "#" character. The characters should form a chessboard.

Passing this string to console.log should show something like this:

# # # #
# # # #
# # # #
# # # #
# # # #
# # # #
# # # #
# # # #
title: Problem 1

content:
The second problem we are going to look at is from the chapter 3 homework
Bean countingYou can get the Nth character, or letter, from a string by writing [N] after the string (for example, string[2]). The resulting value will be a string containing only one character (for example, "b"). The first character has position 0, which causes the last one to be found at position string.length - 1. In other words, a two-character string has length 2, and its characters have positions 0 and 1.Write a function called countBs that takes a string as its only argument and returns a number that indicates how many uppercase B characters there are in the string.
Next, write a function called countChar that behaves like countBs, except it takes a second argument that indicates the character that is to be counted (rather than counting only uppercase B characters). Rewrite countBs to make use of this new function.
// Your code here.
console.log(countBs(“BOB”)); // → 2 console.log(countChar(“kakkerlak”, “k”)); // → 4
My AnswerExplanation of how the code works below
Here’s some interactive code you can try to test it out:
function countBs(str) { return countChar(str);}function countChar(str, charToCount = 'B') { let count = 0;for (let i = 0; i Run Codefunction countBs(str) { return countChar(str);}function countChar(str, charToCount = 'B') { let count = 0;for (let i = 0; i < str.length; i++) {if (str[i] === charToCount) {count++;}}return count;}console.log(countBs("BOB"))// → 2console.log(countChar("kakkerlak", "k"))// → 4 Explanationfunction countBs(str) {this function meets the homework requirment as this just does the counting of the B's and it thats that string that it is given.return countChar(str);}this allows for you to change the character in which you want counted in this case we can now do the letter K.function countChar(str, charToCount = 'B') {this starts the function and makes countchar work it is given the str that it needs to take for example BOB and it is told which character to count in this case the B.let count = 0;it starts off by making the count and that value has to start at 0.for (let i = 0; i < str.length; i++) {this then starts a for loop that that makes i equal to 0 it then checks to see if i is less then the lenght of the string we are given so if the word is "BOB" it would run this code if it was "" meaning blank it would have nothing to count it then adds one to i to make sure we go though every charater in the string.if (str[i] === charToCount) {this then does an if statement that says if the character in the string is equal to the character that we are tring to count then go onto the next code. so for example is we have the string "BOB" and we are counting B's then at str[0] we would have a B but since the charToCount is equal to B then we would contuine.count++;}after the previous code is run and the if statement turns out to be turn then it will run this code which just takes the count and adds one to it.return count;}ones the entire string is done and theres nothing left to count it will run this line which returns the count of whatever value we need.console.log(countBs("BOB"))console.log(countChar("kakkerlak", "k"))this then just makes it so we can see the code that we want and it also defines what string we want to be counted.SourcesClick Here for the link to the textbook for this problem.Click Here for the link to the theme for blowfish on github.
summary:
The second problem we are going to look at is from the chapter 3 homework

Bean counting

You can get the Nth character, or letter, from a string by writing [N] after the string (for example, string[2]). The resulting value will be a string containing only one character (for example, "b"). The first character has position 0, which causes the last one to be found at position string.length - 1. In other words, a two-character string has length 2, and its characters have positions 0 and 1.

Write a function called countBs that takes a string as its only argument and returns a number that indicates how many uppercase B characters there are in the string.
title: Problem 2

content: Hello Reader, this site is my first site that i am putting up with the help of Blowfish and Hugo. the main purpose of this site is to show and explain homework from my CSC 324 class. On this site their will be multiple articles in which show a homework problem and explain how I solved them.
